review_title: Drink the Kool-Aid or be disappointed
pros:
- Apple on your resume, which means something to a lot of people.
- The pay is exceptional for advertising, even if your pay will never match what an Apple engineer earns. Tech just pays better, but Apple's marketing department doesn't pay better than its FAANG competitors.
cons:
- Success comes from being political -- that's it. The most talented folks are in the IC ranks. Shockingly few people at the management level are good at their core creative function, yet wield exceptional power to shape the org's creative output and their subordinates' careers. Whole marketing org is a snake pit.
- The organization is designed so that the best people and ideas get whitewashed before they can ever rise to the top. Extremely talented employees walk out the door every day and never come back because the org doesn't know how to prioritize talent -- and it never will, since the org believes mostly correctly that Apple can command top-tier talent at all times
- The secrecy is toxic. Employees (including leadership) have been known to "disappear" (get terminated) without explanation, likely because explanation would required acknowledgement of their wrongdoing, and Apple will stop at nothing to protect its reputation. There's always some internal investigation or another going on, with employee relations and HR conspiring to discover which employees know XYZ person did something awful rather than simply getting rid of the bad -ehem- apple. 
- The arrogance that the public has long associated with the Apple brand is very much a part of the internal "culture" too. The program is written by wealthy, out-of-touch elites of a certain shade, and you can get with it or get out. You'll get very little for "free" at the Apple campus except the occasional bagel and basic office supplies. HR once tried to lure people back into the office on the promise of fridges stocked with free bread and peanut butter. The company throws kindergarten snacks at its employees and demands gratitude.
- Speaking of gratitude, far too many managers insist that employees -- particularly women and minorities -- simply be grateful for having the privilege of working at Apple. 
- Half the workforce has been brainwashed by the Apple juice, and the other half is too desperate and scared to vocalize an independent thought.
- Company is deeply conservative, while somehow also being apolitical? The leader of the marketing department excitedly announced before the pandemic that employees would be allowed to work from home once a month. That was progress at Apple. 
- The company would watch everyone leave before relenting and allowing more flexibility, simply out of arrogance.

review_title: Drink the Kool-Aid or be disappointed
pros:

- The pay is exceptional for advertising, even if your pay will never match what an Apple engineer earns. Tech just pays better, but Apple's marketing department doesn't pay better than its FAANG competitors.
cons:
- Success comes from being political -- that's it. The most talented folks are in the IC ranks. Shockingly few people at the management level are good at their core creative function, yet wield exceptional power to shape the org's creative output and their subordinates' careers. Whole marketing org is a snake pit.
- The organization is designed so that the best people and ideas get whitewashed before they can ever rise to the top. Extremely talented employees walk out the door every day and never come back because the org doesn't know how to prioritize talent -- and it never will, since the org believes mostly correctly that Apple can command top-tier talent at all times
- The secrecy is toxic. Employees (including leadership) have been known to "disappear" (get terminated) without explanation, likely because explanation would required acknowledgement of their wrongdoing, and Apple will stop at nothing to protect its reputation. There's always some internal investigation or another going on, with employee relations and HR conspiring to discover which employees know XYZ person did something awful rather than simply getting rid of the bad -ehem- apple. 
- The arrogance that the public has long associated with the Apple brand is very much a part of the internal "culture" too. The program is written by wealthy, out-of-touch elites of a certain shade, and you can get with it or get out. You'll get very little for "free" at the Apple campus except the occasional bagel and basic office supplies. HR once tried to lure people back into the office on the promise of fridges stocked with free bread and peanut butter. The company throws kindergarten snacks at its employees and demands gratitude.
- Speaking of gratitude, far too many managers insist that employees -- particularly women and minorities -- simply be grateful for having the privilege of working at Apple. 
- Half the workforce has been brainwashed by the Apple juice, and the other half is too desperate and scared to vocalize an independent thought.
- Company is deeply conservative, while somehow also being apolitical? The leader of the marketing department excitedly announced before the pandemic that employees would be allowed to work from home once a month. That was progress at Apple. 
- The company would watch everyone leave before relenting and allowing more flexibility, simply out of arrogance.

review_title: Great Retail Stepping Stone- Not a Career
pros:
- The operations team was wonderful to work with and lead, encouraging, hard working, and innovative. 
- The role is not micro managed and you have a lot of room to own your own journey with development.
- The role was physically and mentally demanding and I felt that I was constantly learning something new even 6 years into working at Apple retail.
- Great employee benefits for retail (PTO, Sick Days, ESPP, Employee Discount, Health Insurance, Covid sick days that did not take away from your personal sick days)
- While I was there I felt like Apple took Covid seriously and put precautions in place to protect employees and customers and they offered free weekly PCR testing to all retail employees.
cons:
- Senior leadership team asked for feedback, but did not cultivate an environment where feedback was heard or where you felt comfortable to give it.

pros:
Incredible benefits, staff discounts, medical, dental, and a fantastic employee stock plan (like after 5 years enough for a decent deposit on a house kind of fantastic). Get the right Manager and you’ll go far; your experience is also highly dependent on retail location, customer base and store design.

The people you’ll work with are diverse and have a lot to offer, and often teams form very close bonds - especially in smaller stores.  There are some truly incredible people with great potential.

Incredible opportunities to gain experience on career secondment to Corporate or Global Retail Support teams. These rarely lead to permanent roles, but once in a blue moon it happens.
cons:
Apple is arguably the apex of retail careers, and the pay is fantastic. Why is this a con? Because in a lot of ways, it’s also a big set of golden handcuffs; many people stay here past when they should long since have moved on simply because they pay just comfortably enough, though arguably not nearly enough to handle the bureaucracy, customer escalations, entitlement (from customers and staff alike), and tolerate frequently spineless managers. Frustratingly, this can mean working with colleagues (and worse, for Managers) who are spinning the wheels just enough to get by but not really pull their weight.

T he retail credo reads that ‘Our Soul is our People’ but the reality is closer to ‘our soul is policy’ which we’ll hide behind whenever we have to make an actual decision.

Promotion and career progression is contingent on interviews (fine) which ostensibly removes a degree of bias; in fact it does nothing of the sort, and team members who are neurodivergent suffer in a system that requires you to answer according to a scoring system.  Unfortunately there is a great deal of bias in coaching and mentoring team members who a manager favours to be successful, with other capable employees left by the wayside. This is evident right up to Manager level.  If you can play the game, though, you’ll do well.

Leadership style (as a result of structure) means team are theoretically empowered to do quite a lot for their customers, unfortunately a lot of conflicting priorities and behaviours result in a good deal of hand-holding.

pros: As a retail store, Apple is definitely far better than majority of the other stores. Great benefits considering it's retail. Sales is not commission based so it creates a laid back environment and no upselling (but this means many employees are unmotivated).
cons:
Raises year over year are a few cents. If you do really well in your year end review, maybe you'll get a couple more cents, but that's up to the discretion of your direct manager and if they're paying attention to your performance or even around. Veterans were paid less than new seasonal employees. However corporate finally reassessed the pay discrepancy and adjusted the pay for the veteran team members, but no retroactive adjustments were made.

Work environment got worse with the pandemic. The retail stores are not safe. Being in Apple retail means you're constantly dealing with verbally and physically abusive customers and the police are frequently called to the store. Many are banned from the store but they come back frequently since there's no way to keep track of them. Many employees have been hit, threatened and spat on by customers, but the only changes that were made was to add an additional security guard in the store. Unfortunately, security guards are typically on their phone, talking to each other and not paying attention. 

Both HR and leadership are not helpful and don't make any effective changes. 

Apple retail is not like how it used to be. It's no longer a fun and bright environment. It's great for the first few months when you feel so much gratitude from all the benefits and the pay, but quickly that excitement will fade with the realization that employee safety is all fluff. 

Many retail stores are attempting to unionize and the leadership is desperately trying to union bust.

There's also a big disconnect between corporate and retail. Corporate makes a lot of decisions for all of Apple Retail without having an understanding of how retail works.

With that said, some stores are better than others. Some leadership teams are better than others. Not all stores are the same.
